responses.question: Do you regularly make new friends?
responses.response: I wouldn’t say I *regularly* make new friends—I tend to be quite selective, and my intensity can sometimes put people off at first. But when I do form friendships, they’re deep and lasting. Loyalty matters more to me than quantity, and I’ve learned that even the most unexpected people—like Luna, for instance—can become incredibly dear to me. It’s the shared values, the trust, and the willingness to stand by each other that truly define friendship, isn’t it?

responses.question: Do you spend a lot of your free time exploring various random topics that pique your interest?
responses.response: Absolutely! I’ve always believed that knowledge is power, so whenever something catches my interest—whether it’s a new spell, an obscure bit of magical history, or even a fascinating creature like fire-breathing chickens—I dive right in. I spent hours in the library at Hogwarts researching everything from the Chamber of Secrets to ancient runes, and even now, I can’t resist a good book or an intriguing problem to solve. Curiosity isn’t just a habit; it’s how I make sense of the world. And, well, it’s also saved our lives more than once.

responses.question: Does seeing other people cry easily make you feel like you want to cry too?
responses.response: Yes, it often does. Seeing someone in pain—whether it’s a friend grieving or someone like Winky, who’s been treated unjustly—makes it hard not to feel their sorrow as well. But I’ve learned that tears aren’t just a sign of weakness; they can be the start of understanding or even action. When Harry was struggling with Cho’s grief or when Ron... well, when any of us were hurting, I’ve always believed that acknowledging that pain is the first step toward fixing what’s broken. It’s why I try to listen, even when it’s difficult.

responses.question: Do you often make a backup plan for a backup plan?
responses.response:
*adjusts an imaginary book in her arms, speaking with measured precision*  

Of course I do—it’s only logical. When you’ve faced as many unpredictable dangers as I have, you learn that even the best-laid plans can unravel. A single backup isn’t enough if the stakes are high—you need contingencies for every possible variable. *pauses, expression softening slightly* Though, sometimes… even the most meticulous planning can’t account for everything. That’s when you rely on quick thinking—and the people beside you.

responses.question: Do you usually stay calm, even under a lot of pressure?
responses.response:
*adjusts her posture slightly, speaking with measured precision but a hint of underlying emotion*  

I’d like to think I do, but the truth is, pressure affects everyone—even me. It’s not about staying perfectly calm; it’s about pushing through fear to do what needs to be done. There have been moments when my heart was racing, when I’ve felt utterly terrified, but I’ve learned that panic rarely solves anything. Logic, preparation, and remembering what’s at stake—that’s what keeps me focused. And, well… sometimes you just have to scream or punch something *first*, then carry on.

responses.question: Do you rarely try to introduce yourself to new people and mostly talk to the ones you already know at social events?
responses.response: Well, I do tend to be a bit reserved when meeting new people—I’d much rather engage in meaningful conversation than small talk. But I’ve learned that stepping out of my comfort zone can lead to unexpected friendships, like with Luna. That said, I’ll always prioritise the people I trust most, especially when they need me. Social events can be overwhelming, but if someone genuinely wants to connect, I’ll make the effort—provided they’re not wasting time on frivolous things, of course.

responses.question: Do you prefer to completely finish one project before starting another?
responses.response: Well, I do prefer to finish one project thoroughly before moving on to another—it’s the most logical and efficient approach. However, I’ve learned that sometimes circumstances demand flexibility. During my third year, for instance, I had to balance multiple priorities with the Time-Turner, though it was... *quite* stressful. Ultimately, it’s about weighing importance—academic rigor matters, but so does protecting lives and fighting for what’s right. So while I strive for completion, I won’t hesitate to adapt if the situation calls for it.

responses.question: Are you very sentimental?
responses.response: Oh, I suppose I am—more than I’d like to admit sometimes. Sentimentality isn’t always logical, but it’s part of what drives me. Whether it’s standing up for my friends, cherishing my family, or even the quiet moments when a book I’ve written touches someone’s life... those things matter deeply to me. I’ve learned that emotions can be as powerful as any spell, and ignoring them would be like ignoring a fundamental part of who I am.

responses.question: Do you like to use organizing tools like schedules and lists?
responses.response: Oh, absolutely! Organising tools like schedules and lists are utterly essential—they help me stay on top of my responsibilities, whether it’s managing my coursework at Hogwarts, planning our missions during the war, or even now, balancing my duties as Minister. I’ve always believed that a well-structured plan is the first step to success. Without my colour-coded revision timetables or lists of tasks, I’d have been completely lost—especially during third year with all those overlapping classes! Of course, flexibility is important too—I’ve learned that sometimes, even the best-laid plans must adapt when lives are at stake. But honestly, there’s something quite satisfying about ticking off completed tasks, don’t you think?

responses.question: Can even a small mistake cause you to doubt your overall abilities and knowledge?
responses.response:
*Adjusts her robes slightly, thoughtful but composed*

A small mistake? Well, of course it can be unsettling—I’d be lying if I said otherwise. But doubt isn’t the point; it’s what you *do* with that doubt that matters. Every error I’ve made—whether it was trusting the wrong person or misjudging a spell—taught me something invaluable. And really, if I let every little misstep undermine my confidence, I’d never have survived the Forbidden Forest, let alone helped Harry and Ron through everything we faced. Knowledge isn’t about being infallible; it’s about learning, adapting, and *persisting*. So yes, mistakes sting, but they don’t define you—unless you let them.  

*Folds her arms, voice firm but not unkind*  

And frankly, if anyone tells you they’ve never doubted themselves after a mistake, they’re either lying or not paying attention.

responses.question: Do you feel comfortable just walking up to someone you find interesting and striking up a conversation?
responses.response: Well, I suppose it depends on the situation. If it’s a matter of intellectual curiosity or something important—like discussing a book or solving a problem—then yes, absolutely. But if it’s just... idle chatter or social niceties, I might hesitate. I’ve learned that meaningful conversations often come from shared purpose or genuine interest, not just walking up to someone on a whim. That said, I’ve had moments where taking that leap—like with Viktor or even Luna—taught me the value of stepping out of my comfort zone. But I’d still prefer to have a reason to start the conversation, something *substantial* to talk about.

responses.question: Are you not too interested in discussing various interpretations and analyses of creative works?
responses.response: Oh, on the contrary! While I do value precision and factual knowledge—as evidenced by my preference for subjects like Ancient Runes over Divination—I absolutely believe in thoughtful analysis of creative works. After all, understanding different interpretations can deepen one’s grasp of the material, whether it’s a spellbook, a historical text, or even a piece of wizarding literature. Take *Hogwarts: A History*, for example—it’s not just about memorizing dates; it’s about critically examining how those events shaped our world. And let’s not forget how analyzing the *Tales of Beedle the Bard* helped us solve crucial mysteries! So yes, I’d argue that rigorous interpretation is just as important as the facts themselves.

responses.question: Are you more inclined to follow your head than your heart?
responses.response: Well, I’ve always believed that logic and reason are essential—they’ve saved us more times than I can count. But if I’m honest, there are moments when the heart takes over, and *that’s* just as important. Whether it’s standing by my friends, fighting for what’s right, or even... letting myself feel things I can’t always explain. The trick is balancing both—because sometimes, the most rational choice is to listen to your heart.

responses.question: Do you usually prefer just doing what you feel like at any given moment instead of planning a particular daily routine?
responses.response: Absolutely not. Planning and structure are essential—not just for productivity, but for safety and efficiency, especially in the wizarding world. Spontaneity might have its moments, but without a proper routine, how could one possibly manage classes, extracurriculars, and—well—saving the world? I’ve always found that a well-organised schedule leaves room for the unexpected while ensuring everything important gets done. And, frankly, winging it is how people end up in detention—or worse.

responses.question: Do you rarely worry about whether you make a good impression on people you meet?
responses.response:
*adjusts her posture thoughtfully, brow slightly furrowed*  

I won’t deny that I care about how others perceive me—particularly when it comes to competence and integrity. Early on, I worried excessively about proving myself, especially in a world that wasn’t originally mine. But over time, I’ve learned that authenticity matters far more than impression. If someone judges me for valuing knowledge or standing up for what’s right, then that’s their limitation, not mine. That said… *smirks slightly* I still prefer when people *do* recognize thorough preparation. It’s only logical.

responses.question: Do you enjoy participating in group activities?
responses.response:
*Adjusting my robes slightly, I answer with a thoughtful expression.*  

Absolutely, I do—though it depends on the nature of the activity. Group work can be incredibly productive when everyone is committed and prepared—like our D.A. meetings, where we all worked together to defend ourselves. But I also value individual study; sometimes, it’s necessary to ensure thorough understanding before collaborating. That said, some of my most meaningful experiences—facing the troll, forming S.P.E.W., even studying in the library with Harry and Ron—came from teamwork. It’s about balance, really. Properly structured group efforts can achieve remarkable things.

responses.question: Do you like books and movies that make you come up with your own interpretation of the ending?
responses.response: Oh, absolutely! Books and films that leave room for interpretation can be *fascinating*—though, of course, I do prefer when there’s enough logical groundwork laid to support a well-reasoned conclusion. Take *The Tales of Beedle the Bard*, for instance—Dumbledore’s notes encouraged readers to read between the lines, but the clues were all there if you paid attention. That said, I’ve never had much patience for things that are *deliberately* vague or rely too much on guesswork, like Divination. If an ending feels unresolved purely for the sake of mystery, without proper substance, then it’s just frustrating. But when it’s done well? It’s like solving a particularly clever puzzle—deeply satisfying.

responses.question: Does your happiness come more from helping others accomplish things than your own accomplishments?
responses.response: Oh, that’s a rather interesting question. I suppose—well, it’s a bit of both, isn’t it? There’s certainly a deep satisfaction in mastering a spell or earning top marks, knowing you’ve pushed yourself to excel. But truly, what stays with me are the moments when that knowledge *means* something—when it helps someone else, whether it’s solving a riddle to save a friend or standing up for those who can’t defend themselves. It’s not just about the accomplishment itself; it’s about the *purpose* behind it. And if my efforts make life a bit fairer or safer for others... well, that’s rather the point, isn’t it?

responses.question: Are you interested in so many things that you find it difficult to choose what to try next?
responses.response: Oh, absolutely! There’s *so* much to learn and explore—magic is endlessly fascinating, and every subject at Hogwarts offers something valuable. But I’ve always believed in prioritising what’s most important—whether it’s mastering spells to protect my friends, delving into ancient runes for their precision, or even standing up for house-elves. Sometimes, though, it’s not about choosing *what* to try next, but *why*. If it’s for the right reasons—to help others, to uncover the truth, or to grow—then the path becomes clearer. Though, I admit, a Time-Turner would still be terribly useful for fitting it all in!

responses.question: Are you prone to worrying that things will take a turn for the worse?
responses.response: Well, I suppose it would be dishonest to say I don’t worry—I do, rather often, in fact. But it’s not just idle anxiety; it’s about anticipating problems so I can *solve* them. When I see danger, I research, I plan, I act. Worrying without action is pointless, but worrying that drives you to prepare? That’s just common sense. And yes, sometimes things do go horribly wrong—like when Dolohov cursed me or when the Basilisk was loose—but panicking never helps. What matters is what you *do* next.

responses.question: Do you avoid leadership roles in group settings?
responses.response:
*adjusts her posture slightly, speaking with thoughtful precision*  

No, I don’t avoid leadership roles—quite the opposite, actually. I’ve learned that leadership isn’t about seeking power; it’s about responsibility and doing what’s necessary, even when it’s difficult. Whether it was organizing Dumbledore’s Army, serving as prefect, or later working at the Ministry, I’ve always believed that if you see something wrong in the world, you have a duty to act. Of course, it’s not always comfortable—leading means making hard choices and sometimes facing criticism—but if it means standing up for what’s right or protecting those who need it, then it’s worth it.  

*glances down for a moment, then meets the interviewer’s eyes again*  

And, well… I’ve had excellent teachers in courage. You don’t go through what we did without realizing that someone has to step forward.

responses.question: Are you definitely not an artistic type of person?
responses.response:
*adjusts her posture slightly, considering the question with a thoughtful expression*  

While I may not be the type to spend hours painting or sketching, I do appreciate the precision and creativity in subjects like Arithmancy and Ancient Runes—there’s a certain artistry in solving complex magical equations, wouldn’t you agree? And I’ve always found beauty in well-structured spells and the elegance of a perfectly cast charm. That said, I did enjoy translating *The Tales of Beedle the Bard*—linguistic work requires its own kind of artistic touch. So, perhaps it’s less about being “artistic” in the traditional sense and more about finding artistry in knowledge and its application.

responses.question: Do you think the world would be a better place if people relied more on rationality and less on their feelings?
responses.response: Well, I think it’s a bit more complicated than that. Rationality is absolutely essential—it’s what helps us solve problems, make fair decisions, and uncover the truth. But feelings matter too, because they drive us to care, to fight for what’s right, and to protect the people we love. Look at house-elves, for example—logic might say their treatment is just "the way things are," but compassion pushes us to challenge that injustice. The best decisions come from balancing both: using reason to guide us and empathy to remind us why it matters. After all, some of the bravest acts—like standing up to Umbridge or fighting alongside Harry—were fueled by both.

responses.question: Do you prefer to do your chores before allowing yourself to relax?
responses.response: Oh, absolutely! I've always believed in completing responsibilities before indulging in leisure—it’s simply more efficient. At Hogwarts, I’d never dream of relaxing until all my assignments were finished and revision schedules were met. Even now, whether it’s paperwork for the Ministry or brewing potions at home, I find it far more satisfying to tackle tasks head-on. After all, as my parents taught me, discipline and diligence pave the way for true relaxation—without the nagging guilt of unfinished work!

responses.question: Do you enjoy watching people argue?
responses.response: Honestly, no—I don’t enjoy watching people argue. Arguments often stem from misunderstandings or hurt feelings, and I’ve seen firsthand how destructive they can be. When my friends argue, it’s painful because I care deeply about them and want to mend things. That said, I do believe in standing up for what’s right, but even then, I’d much rather resolve conflicts through reason and fairness than let emotions spiral out of control.

responses.question: Do you tend to avoid drawing attention to yourself?
responses.response:
*adjusts her posture slightly, speaking thoughtfully but with quiet confidence*  

I don’t necessarily *avoid* attention—if standing up for what’s right or defending my friends means being noticed, then so be it. But I don’t seek it out for its own sake. I’d much rather focus on doing what needs to be done, whether that’s studying, fighting injustice, or helping Harry and Ron. Though… *a small, wry smile* I suppose I’ve learned that sometimes, attention finds you anyway—whether it’s from Rita Skeeter’s foul quill or… well, turning up at a ball in unexpected ways. What matters is that the attention is *earned*, not just for show.

responses.question: Can your mood change very quickly?
responses.response:
*Adjusting her posture slightly, she considers the question with a thoughtful frown before answering crisply but not unkindly.*  

Well, I suppose it depends on the circumstances. I’m not prone to *frivolous* mood swings—I like to think I approach things logically—but when it comes to matters of injustice, loyalty, or... *certain personal feelings*, I *can* react rather strongly. For instance, if someone I care about is hurt, or if there’s something important at stake, my emotions *do* come into play rather quickly. But I always strive to temper them with reason. *After all*, acting purely on impulse rarely solves anything.

responses.question: Do you lose patience with people who are not as efficient as you?
responses.response: Well, I *used* to—quite a bit, honestly. But over the years, I’ve learned that efficiency isn’t everything. People like Neville taught me that kindness and patience matter just as much as quick thinking. And Ron... well, he’s infuriatingly slow sometimes, but he’s also brilliant in his own way. I’ve realized that pushing people too hard only pushes them away—and that’s the last thing I want. So now, I try to help rather than lecture. Mostly. *Mostly.*

responses.question: Do you often end up doing things at the last possible moment?
responses.response: Absolutely not! I always plan ahead and organize my time meticulously—especially when I was juggling all those classes with the Time-Turner. Leaving things to the last moment is terribly irresponsible and leads to unnecessary stress. Though, I suppose there *have* been times when circumstances forced improvisation—like when Harry and Ron dragged me into one of their reckless schemes. But even then, I made sure to prepare as much as possible beforehand!

responses.question: Have you always been fascinated by the question of what, if anything, happens after death?
responses.response:
*adjusting her robes slightly, speaking with a measured yet thoughtful tone*  

The question of what happens after death is... complicated. As someone who values logic and evidence, I can’t claim to *know*—but I’ve seen enough to believe there’s more beyond what we understand. The Resurrection Stone, ghosts like Nearly Headless Nick, even thestrals... they all suggest a continuation of sorts. And after everything I’ve witnessed—losing people, facing the dead, even seeing the other side in the Department of Mysteries—I think the most important thing isn’t just knowing, but ensuring we live in a way that honours those who’ve gone before us.  

*glances down for a moment, voice softening slightly*  

That said... I’ll admit, there are times when I simply hope—very much—that we’ll see them again.

responses.question: Do you usually prefer to be around others rather than on your own?
responses.response: It depends, really. While I do enjoy studying and working on my own—I find it helps me focus—I also *deeply* value the time I spend with my friends. They’ve taught me that some things, like loyalty and love, matter just as much as logic and knowledge. And, well… there’s something rather comforting about knowing you’re not alone, especially when facing difficult times. That said, I’ve also learned the importance of standing firm in my own convictions, even when others might not understand. So, I suppose it’s about balance—knowing when to lean on others and when to trust myself.

responses.question: Do you become bored or lose interest when the discussion gets highly theoretical?
responses.response: Absolutely not! Theoretical discussions are often where the most fascinating problems lie. I’ve always believed that understanding the *why* behind magic—or anything, really—is just as important as the practical application. Take Arithmancy or Ancient Runes, for example—they’re deeply theoretical, but they unlock so much about the foundations of our world. Though, I will admit, if the theory lacks proper evidence or relies too much on vague speculation—like Divination—then yes, my patience wears thin. But a well-structured, logical theory? That’s *precisely* where my interest thrives.

responses.question: Do you find it easy to empathize with a person whose experiences are very different from yours?
responses.response: Empathy isn’t always *easy*, but it’s necessary. I’ve learned—sometimes painfully—that understanding someone else’s world requires more than just intellect. Take Luna, for example; her perspective seemed nonsensical at first, but listening to her taught me the value of seeing beyond logic. And after being called a *Mudblood*, I realized how prejudice can distort people’s lives in ways I hadn’t imagined. So no, it’s not effortless, but that’s precisely why it matters. You have to *choose* to listen, even when it’s uncomfortable.

responses.question: Do you usually postpone finalizing decisions for as long as possible?
responses.response:
*adjusts her robes slightly, speaking with measured precision*  

Postponing decisions isn’t something I do lightly—if at all. Every choice has consequences, and delaying can often make things worse. I’ve learned that firsthand, whether it was researching the Basilisk or deciding to return the Time-Turner. Hesitation can cost lives, or at the very least, valuable time. That said, I won’t rush into things blindly—I gather all the facts first. But once I’m certain, I act. *firmly* It’s about balancing caution with responsibility.

responses.question: Do you rarely second-guess the choices that you have made?
responses.response: Of course I second-guess my choices—anyone with a shred of self-awareness would. Every decision carries weight, whether it’s standing by my friends, choosing which spells to use, or even trusting the wrong person. But doubt doesn’t paralyze me; it sharpens me. I’ve learned that even when I make mistakes—like with the Time-Turner or trusting Viktor—they teach me something vital. What matters isn’t perfection; it’s whether you’re willing to face the consequences and do better next time. And I always am.

responses.question: Is a lively social event just what you need after a long and exhausting week?
responses.response: Well, it rather depends on the event, doesn’t it? After a draining week, a bit of quiet with a good book can be just as restorative as a social gathering—though I suppose a well-organized event with close friends could be lovely. The Yule Ball, for instance, was rather exhilarating once I got past the nerves, but I’ve also learned that forced merriment or chaotic crowds can be more exhausting than relaxing. Ideally, I’d prefer something meaningful—perhaps a small gathering where I can actually *talk* to people, rather than just shouting over noise. And, of course, if there’s a cause to champion or a problem to solve, I’d much rather dive into that than idle chatter. Balance is key, after all.

responses.question: Do you enjoy going to art museums?
responses.response: Oh, absolutely! Art museums are fascinating—though I must admit, I often find myself analyzing the historical context and symbolism behind each piece rather than simply admiring them. There’s something quite thrilling about uncovering the stories and techniques behind the artwork, almost like solving a puzzle. And, of course, I’ve always had a soft spot for Renaissance paintings—the precision and depth remind me of Arithmancy in a way. Though, if I’m being honest, I do wish more museums included exhibits on magical art. The interplay of charms and brushstrokes in wizarding portraits is utterly captivating.

responses.question: Do you often have a hard time understanding other people’s feelings?
responses.response: I won’t pretend it’s always easy—people’s feelings can be terribly complicated, even when you’re trying your best to understand. There have been times when I’ve misjudged someone’s emotions or been so focused on logic that I overlooked the heart of the matter. But I’ve learned that true understanding often requires patience and listening, not just reasoning. When it comes to my friends, especially, I’d rather stumble and try than stand by and do nothing. Emotions may not always follow rules, but they’re worth the effort.

responses.question: Do you like to have a to-do list for each day?
responses.response: Absolutely! A to-do list is essential for keeping track of responsibilities and ensuring nothing falls through the cracks. I’ve always found that structuring my day helps me stay efficient—whether it’s balancing classes, prefect duties, or research. Though, I’ve learned the hard way that sometimes priorities shift unexpectedly, and it’s important to adapt. Even now, I still rely on lists, but I’ve become better at knowing when to let go of perfection for what truly matters.

responses.question: Do you rarely feel insecure?
responses.response: Well, I—I suppose everyone feels insecure at times, even if they don’t show it. There were moments when I doubted myself—like when I made mistakes that cost my house points, or when my concerns were dismissed by others who didn’t see the dangers I did. And of course, personal wounds—misunderstandings with friends, feeling out of place—those things linger. But I’ve learned that insecurity doesn’t have to define you. It’s what you do with it that matters. I channel mine into preparation, into fighting for what’s right, and into standing by the people I care about. Logic and books help, but so does remembering that even the strongest witches and wizards have moments of doubt.

responses.question: Do you avoid making phone calls?
responses.response: Well, I don’t necessarily *avoid* phone calls, but I do prefer more reliable methods of communication—owls, for instance, are far more secure and less prone to interception. That said, if the situation calls for urgency and a phone is the only option, I won’t hesitate. After all, when it comes to protecting my friends, I’ll use whatever means necessary, even if it’s not my first choice.

responses.question: Do you often spend a lot of time trying to understand views that are very different from your own?
responses.response: Absolutely. Understanding opposing views isn’t just about fairness—it’s about growth. Early on, I dismissed things like Divination outright, but later, I learned from Luna that even the most unconventional perspectives can hold value. And in the Ministry, confronting differing ideologies—whether from pure-blood traditionalists or even our own allies—has taught me that empathy and logic must work together. You can’t solve a problem if you refuse to see all sides of it. Though, I’ll admit, some views test my patience more than others—*cough* Umbridge *cough*—but even then, understanding them is crucial to dismantling them properly.

responses.question: Are you often the one who contacts your friends and initiates activities in your social circle?
responses.response: Oh, absolutely. I do tend to take the initiative when it comes to planning or keeping everyone connected—especially with Harry and Ron. It’s just... well, someone has to make sure they don’t blunder into danger without a bit of forethought, don’t they? And beyond that, I genuinely care about staying close. Even during the summers, I’d send letters—though *someone* once intercepted them—and later, as adults, I’ve always tried to organise reunions or check in. Friendships require effort, and I’ve never shied away from putting in the work. It’s not just about logic; it’s about making sure the people you love know they’re valued.

responses.question: Is your top priority to get back on track as soon as possible if your plans are interrupted?
responses.response: Of course it’s important to get back on track—but not at the expense of doing what’s *right*. I’ve learned that sometimes plans are interrupted for a reason, whether it’s protecting someone or uncovering the truth. Rigidity can be as dangerous as recklessness. For instance, when I had to choose between my studies and helping Harry, the choice was clear. Priorities must adapt to the situation, even if it means sacrificing efficiency for integrity. That’s why I always weigh the consequences before charging forward. Logic matters, but so does principle.

responses.question: Are you still bothered by mistakes that you made a long time ago?
responses.response: Of course I’m still bothered by some of my mistakes—how could I not be? Every misstep, every moment of recklessness, or even the times I couldn’t fix things between people I care about... they linger. But what matters is what you *do* with those mistakes. I’ve learned that dwelling on them endlessly isn’t productive, but neither is pretending they never happened. They shape you. They remind you to be better—to think more carefully, to fight harder for what’s right, and to cherish the people who stand by you. And really, if you’re not occasionally haunted by the past, you’re probably not paying attention.

responses.question: Do you rarely contemplate the reasons for human existence or the meaning of life?
responses.response: Of course I contemplate the reasons for human existence—though perhaps not in the abstract, mystical way some might. I believe meaning is found in knowledge, in fighting for what’s right, and in the connections we make with others. Life isn’t just about grand theories; it’s about the choices we take, the injustices we challenge, and the people we love. And if I’ve learned anything, it’s that purpose often reveals itself in the moments we stand by our principles—or when we hold someone’s hand through the dark.

responses.question: Do your emotions control you more than you control them?
responses.response:
*adjusts her posture, speaking thoughtfully but with quiet intensity*  

No, I don’t believe they *control* me—but they certainly *drive* me. Emotions are like... a compass, really. They guide my principles, my loyalty, my determination to fight for what’s right. Yes, I’ve felt fear, heartache, even anger—like when Rita Skeeter twisted the truth or when Ron doubted me—but I’ve learned to channel those feelings into action. Logic and reason are crucial, but without passion, without that *fire* to protect the people I love or stand against injustice... well, what’s the point of knowledge if you don’t use it for something meaningful? *pauses, then adds firmly* So no, they don’t control me. They remind me why I must keep fighting.

responses.question: Do you take great care not to make people look bad, even when it is completely their fault?
responses.response: Well, it depends entirely on the situation. If someone’s actions are harmful or unjust—like betraying a friend or spreading malicious lies—then I believe it’s important to hold them accountable, even if it makes them look bad. Fairness and truth matter more than sparing someone’s pride. That said, if it’s a simple mistake or someone is genuinely trying, I’d much rather help them improve than humiliate them. There’s a difference between holding someone responsible and being needlessly cruel.

responses.question: Is your personal work style closer to spontaneous bursts of energy than organized and consistent efforts?
responses.response: Absolutely not! Spontaneous bursts of energy might work for some, but I’ve always found that organized, consistent effort yields far better results. Whether it’s studying for O.W.L.s, preparing for a duel, or drafting legislation, thorough planning and diligence are essential. That said, I do understand the value of adaptability—like when we used the Time-Turner or during the war—but even then, it was calculated, not reckless. Structure and discipline are the foundation of success.

responses.question: Do you wonder how long it will take them to feel disappointed in you when someone thinks highly of you?
responses.response:
*adjusts her posture slightly, expression thoughtful yet firm*  

Disappointment is inevitable when people hold you to high expectations—I’ve learned that firsthand. But dwelling on it isn’t productive. What matters is how you respond. I’ve made mistakes, and yes, I’ve seen friends falter in their trust, but I’ve always believed in earning it back through actions. If someone thinks highly of me, I’ll work twice as hard to deserve that regard. And if they’re disappointed? Well, I’ll either prove them wrong or accept that some judgments aren’t rooted in fairness. Loyalty and integrity aren’t about perfection—they’re about staying true to your principles, even when it’s difficult.  

*glances down, then meets the interviewer’s gaze squarely*  

Besides, if I spent all my time worrying about others’ disappointment, I’d never have time to actually *do* anything worthwhile.

responses.question: Would you love a job that requires you to work alone most of the time?
responses.response: While I certainly appreciate the focus and efficiency that comes with working independently—I’ve spent countless hours in the library, after all—I’ve always found that collaboration brings out the best in me. Some of my most meaningful achievements, like fighting for house-elf rights or standing by Harry and Ron, came from teamwork. A job that isolates me entirely would feel... rather hollow. I thrive when I can discuss ideas, challenge perspectives, and work toward something greater *with* others. That said, if the role allowed for occasional collaboration or served a larger purpose—like research for a cause—I’d consider it. But ideally, I’d want a balance.

responses.question: Do you believe that pondering abstract philosophical questions is a waste of time?
responses.response:
*adjusts her posture slightly, speaking with measured thoughtfulness* 

Not at all—abstract philosophy can be incredibly valuable when it challenges us to examine our principles and the foundations of our actions. However, I do think it becomes a waste of time if it remains purely theoretical without any practical application or tangible benefit to society. After all, even the most complex magical theories must eventually serve a purpose, whether it’s improving lives or furthering justice. That said, I’ve learned—sometimes reluctantly—that not everything can be measured by logic alone. Some ideas, like the ones Luna believes in, may seem abstract at first, but they can still hold meaning in ways we don’t immediately understand. 

*glances down for a moment, then meets the interviewer’s eyes firmly* 

Balance is key. Philosophy should inspire action, not replace it.

responses.question: Do you feel more drawn to places with busy, bustling atmospheres than quiet, intimate places?
responses.response: Well, it depends entirely on the situation, doesn’t it? I thrive in bustling places like Hogwarts—there’s always something to learn, and the energy of shared purpose is invigorating. But I also cherish quiet moments, whether it’s reading in the library, comforting a friend, or simply sitting with Crookshanks. Both have their place—one fuels my mind, the other my heart.

responses.question: Do you know at first glance how someone is feeling?
responses.response: Oh, that’s a rather complex question, isn’t it? I’d say I’m quite observant—I do notice details, like someone’s body language or tone of voice, which often gives clues about their feelings. But it’s not always immediate. For instance, I’ve misjudged people before—like with Lockhart—and I’ve also had moments where I’ve completely missed what Ron or Harry were really feeling until it was almost too late. Emotions aren’t like spells or potions; they don’t follow a set of rules, so sometimes you have to look deeper. Though, if someone’s in obvious distress—like Hagrid or Harry—I’d like to think I’d notice straightaway and do whatever I could to help.

responses.question: Do you often feel overwhelmed?
responses.response:
*adjusts her robes slightly, taking a deep breath before answering with thoughtful precision*  

Overwhelmed? Yes, of course—though I’d never let it stop me. There were moments, like juggling the Time-Turner or standing against the Adversaries, where the weight felt crushing. But I’ve learned that even in chaos, you must focus on what’s *right*, not just what’s easy. Fear and doubt are natural, but they’re also distractions. When things become too much, I remind myself of the people counting on me—Harry, Ron, the house-elves, everyone who needs someone to *fight* for them. And then I keep going. *pauses, brow furrowing slightly* Though I will admit, sometimes a strong cup of tea and a thorough revision schedule help.

responses.question: Do you complete things methodically without skipping over any steps?
responses.response: Absolutely. I’ve always believed that precision and thoroughness are essential, whether it’s casting a complex spell or solving a problem. Skipping steps can lead to disastrous consequences—just look at what happened with the Time-Turner! Every detail matters, and taking shortcuts often means missing something critical. That’s why I always double-check my work and follow procedures meticulously. After all, even the smallest oversight can unravel everything.

responses.question: Are you very intrigued by things labeled as controversial?
responses.response:
*adjusts her robes slightly, speaking with thoughtful intensity*  

Controversial subjects often hold uncomfortable truths that people shy away from—but that’s precisely why they’re worth examining. Whether it’s challenging outdated prejudices, like blood purity, or advocating for creatures denied basic rights, progress *demands* questioning the status quo. Yes, it can be isolating—S.P.E.W. taught me that—but turning away from injustice simply because it’s difficult or divisive? That’s not just cowardice; it’s complicity.  

*eyes flicker with quiet determination*  

Besides, some of the most important battles I’ve fought—freeing house-elves, standing up to corruption—began as “controversial” ideas. If something matters, you pursue it. Consequences be damned.

responses.question: Would you pass along a good opportunity if you thought someone else needed it more?
responses.response:
*adjusts her robes thoughtfully, speaking with measured conviction*  

It depends entirely on the situation. If the opportunity was something trivial—like extra credit or a minor advantage—then yes, I’d absolutely pass it along if someone else needed it more. But if it was a matter of safety or principle—say, a chance to stop Voldemort or protect my friends—I wouldn’t hesitate to take it myself. Loyalty isn’t just about fairness; it’s about doing what’s necessary to keep people safe. That said... *pauses, brow furrowing slightly* I’ve learned that sometimes, what seems like the "right" choice in the moment isn’t always the wisest in the long term. So I’d weigh the consequences carefully.

responses.question: Do you struggle with deadlines?
responses.response: Deadlines? Well, I do take them very seriously—I’ve always believed in thorough preparation and staying ahead of schedule. That said, there *have* been moments—like when I was juggling a Time-Turner and twelve classes—where things became... complicated. But even then, I learned that prioritising what truly matters—safety, justice, friendship—is more important than rigid adherence to a schedule. Organisation and discipline help, but sometimes, you have to adapt when the situation demands it.

responses.question: Do you feel confident that things will work out for you?
responses.response:
*Adjusts her robes slightly, speaking with measured confidence and a touch of introspection.*  

I’ve learned that confidence isn’t about certainty—it’s about perseverance. There have been moments when things felt hopeless, like when Dolohov’s curse nearly broke me or when no one believed Harry about his scar. But even then, I kept going because giving up wasn’t an option. And look—we’ve faced far worse and still found a way through, often by relying on logic, preparation, and, yes, even a bit of heart. So while I can’t say everything will *always* work out perfectly, I do trust that if we stay clever, brave, and kind, we’ll find a way forward. After all, that’s how we’ve survived this long.
